<@U0542GLTE>: since you are in charge of android hiring, how hard is it to find android devs in US?
Dude, I have been trying to hire since February for two
and thus far, I have 0
^ what he said
Nobody knows shit. I get so many bullshit resumes.
People going, oh yeah, I did this and this and this.
It's basically, they write something simple out of Big nerd ranch, or some calculator or something. Zero idea of what's really going on
oh man so it’s like over here then
that sucks
its everywhere
we hire remote people
I’d assume since it’s a bigger market there’s going to be a lot more devs
no one knows anythin'
and the people that do, have jobs and dont want to leave
makes me wonder what happens to everyone graduating from CS universities
they find jobs writing code that's not android
My Junior iOS guy almost straight out of school knows more about iOS than the Android people I have interviewed.
eh but here around 4000 people graduate CS every year… combining all dev companies in my country would be like 7-8000 people maybe
And I thought there are so many mobile devs around since "it's the shit" and "mobile everything"
<@U04TK850N>:  that’s why I’m like wtf, I know RoR and JS are hot stuff too, but android is also
But that explains why a friend complained so much about useless devs on a big android project we have
Apparently they know nothing

The problem with Android is actually very classic and easy to explain. I was forced into Android due to a contract with a mobile carrier who didn't carry the iPhone. I found it a good way to generate additional income for me too. I would give the iPhone quote at 18k (Backend + Design + the App) and then say, I'll give you Android for 5k more.
One of our android devs actually said fuck it and went back to backend Java :D

So it got me experience. On the flip side, everyone else is like... iOS $$$$$... so they did that and said fuck android... now, at least in Orlando, Android devs are pulling in more money than iOS because there aren't that many of us with experience
wow, here iOS is a lot more rare, mostly because Macs are rare
I'm so happy most of our clients have no idea what the stuff we do would cost from the free market :D
eh clients are like Jon Snow
they know nothing
Haha
I’m thinking of maybe turning a bit towards Java EE or Go
lol. Just started watching GoT last week, and actually know who that is now.... small successes.
oh get ready for an emotional rollercoaster, that show is one
Yeah, I'm on the second episode of season 3 now.
Also get ready for waiting a year for next season ._.
this is so fucking shitty. we’ve been watching it for 5 years now and we know nothing
It's like toying with a fat kid and cake... here you want this...how good is it... ohh, btw loaded with laxatives... have fun watching your character die.
like I’m going to spend my 20s watching for new seasons
lol
*waiting
*your character and all other characters
they should just get a new cast every season
For the times between seasons are dark and full of terror
I was telling one of my friends, George is going to die.... we are going to have to freeze him, transplant his brain ASAP... and then we will finally get the end of it in like 2045

anything in particular?
Oh wait, I fail at geography, nvm
well, explain your philosophies I suppose

closer to where someone I know lives ;D
<@U060Q7J2Y>: there are plenty of ways to architect an Android app, how do you guys do it?
we use all the "hotness" - dagger, rxjava, etc
if that's what you're asking
we have tests
unlike a lot of places
unlike myself then :stuck_out_tongue:
:stuck_out_tongue:
#winning
I also attempted dagger (albeit via kotlin), but found that it offered very little benefit for the boilerplate involved
so I wouldn't say I'm sold on it yet
Dagger 2 doesn’t have that much boilerplate
a module and component
we dont use dagger 2
<@U0548MM6B>: it's all boilerplate
not much boilerplate
in dagger 1
no components either
<@U060Q7J2Y>: yes, well I remember trying my hand at dagger 1 and being entirely confused, so I can't say I find it any more preferable to dagger 2 :confused:
Yeah, I really get confused when people say there are is a lot of boiler plate in dagger
I worked with both and find 2 preferable
i'd write a blog post but no one seems to care about dagger 1 anymore
and with no plans to move, i have no reason to write one for d2
The big question is, what do you consider a >good< Android developer? How to you determine that. I mean, if I needed to show you that I'm good, what would you want to see?
<@U0542GLTE>: dagger is just structured boilerplate, that's all
<@U04TK850N>: do you have apps in the play store?
yeah... no. none that are actually my own

at the very least

well yeah
I guess it is an issue then, that we mostly do inhouse stuff
<@U060Q7J2Y>: perhaps, but testing is something else I'm resistant to spend time on :simple_smile:
wat
<@U04TK850N>:  hah, same thing, I don’t have any apps in the play store of my own. but there is at least 10 apps I’ve worked on that are in store
i dont care if they are yours personally
but i'd likely ask you about what you did for them, etc
I have a fork of another app in the store
And the only other thing I could show would be the one from the current project, which happens to be one of the most downloaded apps in Germany :smile:
But I'm not that proud of it considering how the designers fucked up the whole UI/UX :confused:

so I was looking up some app pre-release checklists to see if people are doing anything that I have been overlooking, and a lot of people were mentioning to include android:installLocation=”preferExternal” in the manifest. is this a common best practice?
i've not heard that
i looked for some official google documentation and they say to make sure your app functions when installed to an external sd card
but it doesn’t say to add that explicitly
i've never set that on any app i've ever worked on
yeah, might be an outdated practice or something
didnt even know that was an option
okay, probably not a big deal then
we have a widget, which IIRC prevents us from being moved to SD (but I don't remember if thats true)
<http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/manifest-intro.html>
